more facts talking to my staff talking

others who are involved in the

has governed me throughout my years of

first started in the state legislature

other members of the gang of six you've
not supported that bill but said you

right
track and it just needs a few

struggle you know with you know the
magnitude and scope of any major

represents so much change so one is you
know my concern about some of the
individual components such as the
individual mandate secondly the
affordability question and although I

available to American people affordable

that's what they truly expect from any

additional 37 billion over those last
weeks because I was so concerned about
the fact that we couldn't drive down the

the individual parts of it that I'm

will be moving in the right direction we
want to build upon what's best about a

it's looking at the overall picture as
well as individual parts that make up
the whole but does that I'm trying to
understand whether or not you think with
a few amendments in committee that that

you want are you more inclined to say

that necessarily had to start over
because there's some very important

creating competition is them drive the

achieve lower prices even the

through the efficiencies of the
marketplace income and price shopping
they'll be available to consumers also
removing many egregious practices in the
part of the
surance companies in rescinding policies
you know I'm not allowing guaranteed
issue unless the state has obviously

denied health care health insurance
because of their previous existing
condition or because of the health

we certainly address all of those key

market individual markets tax credit
subsidies all moving I think in in the

you know with signing up for health
insurance plan in those penalties that

requirement would be affordability well
does that mean that you think the bill

that's right and that's that's the

mean that you know the the majority you
know of the provisions of the

you want more of those so yeah they
would have to be more subsidies and
driving down the prices I mean I think

have expressed a desire to be able to
you know buy plans in the exchange even

people will be able to go price shopping
even if they aren't eligible for a

drive down those prices will be more

but the question is how much it
subsidies can we afford to provide to
middle-income America and that's the key
now whether or not you have an

you tie the subsidies to a lesser plan
in the exchange right now it's tired too
it's tied to the second best you know
the second plan so in other words one
way to afford more subsidies is to
ratchet down the love
of plan that you're requiring people to
have that's right well yes there are
four different plans in the exchange you
have the bronze it'll be available as
well to young adults and then you'd have

which is the one which the subsidies
would be tied to which is you know a
good plan it's a generous plan maybe we
give people more choices in terms of
their options but the second part of it
is the level of the penalty that's
involved with the individual mandate I
have some you know deep reservations
about requiring people to pay a heavy

he's going to you know reduce that

will go further and want to drive down

good enough for you know I'd like to
even I would like to go a little bit

so she especially young people you know
if you get your on try to capture the 10

but on the other hand that we want to

they end up with no health care coverage
I mean the point is then pay a penalty
i'd like to pay it towards coverage ret
as opposed to just as simple you know as

are you satisfied that the cost control
cost containment in the bill is adequate
I I do and I you know we had that
discussion this morning with the
congressional budget office director
Doug Elmendorf with whom we work hand in
glove in a group of sex I mean we were
adamant in our you know our positions
and views that it should be budget
neutral and if anything should bend the
cost curve and bend the overall cost you
know the escalation you know of
inflation within healthcare and it does
begin that trend in the first ten years
he indicated that it could be less
certain about the second ten-year window
because you know they can only define it
in broad terms is probably going to
bring down the cost of health care but
obviously it's going to be done with
less certainty and predictability
because it's so far out but the point is
is budget neutral it does reduce the
deficit that is an important direction
and we were all you know insistent upon
that and so I think that there's a very
positive aspect to this plan because it
is critically important and frankly I
know some of my colleagues have
indicated well you know we could you
know Congress could change these
provisions in the future and therefore
adds to the cost of the bill at you know
takes away the budget neutrality on the
other hand we could have a requirement
to insist that any changes in this
particular plan will have to be paid for
and fully offset so we always maintain
its budget neutrality and continue on
that trend that's correct you're
identified as a supporter somebody who
offered the idea in discussion of the
so-called triggered public option are
you going to offer that as amendment in
committee and if you get that it's clear
to me the White House would accept a
triggered public option if you get that
amendment
are you likely to support the bill would
that be important well the i offered the
trigger many months ago as an idea and
alternative to the public option and i
mentioned that to the president at that
time you know he didn't reject it and in
the ensuing conversations I've had with
him and others they indicated there
would be flexibility and act on that
point I think now it's the question as
to whether or not you know we you know
at which point to address that issue and
I think we'll have to determine whether
or not saan the committee or on the
floor and and how we build a consensus
at that point in addition to the other
issues so that's more likely you would
offer that on the floor that in
committee it could be and I have to get
a sense of it I mean they're going to be
a number of amendments in the committee
markup and obviously it's going to
evolve depending on you know what where
the support is and whether or not it's
better to offer it on the floor to a
broader group than in the committee
itself senator Baucus and the President
and other Democrats who were trying to
make this happen have made appeals to
the sense of history that after so many
decades of failing to pass comprehensive
reform this is the time to do it do you
have a similar feeling well I think the
time has come but it's also critical to
affect the right policy because it
affect it affects every American and how
we craft that policy will have you know
a tremendous impact on the country and
on something that is so fundamentally
important to the American people so it's
important to get it right and so I have
argued from the outset that let's not be
bound by artificial timetables and
arbitrary deadlines in order to get it
done let's develop a comfort level
within you know within the Senate within
the Congress that ultimately will
engender the confidence of the American
people and the kind of product that we
ultimately a draft so I think from that
standpoint it was important i think that
the time has come in terms of the cost
that whether you have health insurance
you're here health insurance is in
jeopardy because of the rising costs and
for those who don't who obviously are
going to find it it's more and more out
of reach and very difficult to ever
obtained you have a good sense of the
rhythms of this place having served for

the level of interaction that you're
having with the White House with Senator
Baucus and others that you're going to
end up supporting a package this year
well it again it depends on what we do
in the committee I would like to you
know support a bipartisan consensus
based package on the right policy and at
the end of the day what is absolutely
essential and imperative is to construct
the right policy the American people
have confidence in at a time in which
they lack the confidence in their major
institutions and elected officials so
it's critically important that we do
everything that we can to draft the very
best approach to overhauling your health
care system and that means taking the
time to get it done not saying well it
has to be done in a week or two weeks so
I want to give it my level best as I
have up to this point I want to continue
that process you have to continue to
hear you know differing views and
approaches and see if we can work
through and sort of the process I think
that's the oven flow the legislative
process what are you optimistic that
that's going to end I think Aegis latian
well it's you know it's hard to tell yes
I'm probably more optimistic than less
but I think it all I think we'll get a

without of our hands in the final

and will continue to road their health

well be a snow I don't be i know that

Ghana the votes so do you think if you

that's you know what I've always done
that has been my guiding light frankly

essential been making it happen for the
for the country we've gotten too much

become Democrats just like to ask you
why are you a Republican and how

always been a Republican for the
traditional principles that have been
associated the Republican Party since I
you know became a Republican when I
registered to vote and that is limited
government individual opportunities
fiscal responsibility and
strong national defense so I think that
those principles have always been a part
of the Republican Party heritage and I
believe that I you know reflect those
fuse and I haven't changed as a
Republican I think more that my party
has changed are you getting a lot of
heat pressure from fellow Republicans no
I mean I think understandably they
overall concerned about you know what
kind of health care policy will emerge
and so therefore you know looking at the

understand that you know this issue
needs to be addressed and how best to

you know for solutions or what you know
what they can do to improve upon what is

so they understand that and so I don't
think it's just necessarily being
opposed but they'll come up with an

Republicans should stand for something
on this issue because it's it's so
important to the American people and
just because it's difficult doesn't mean
that we shouldn't assume the
responsibility of addressing it so
thanks so much for doing thank you
